The *pdhA* gene encodes the alpha subunit of the pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) complex's E1 component, which catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. This reaction links glycolysis to the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle and is essential for central carbon metabolism. In cyanobacteria like *Synechocystis*, the PDH complex utilizes NAD⁺ and is universally present across all analyzed cyanobacterial genomes[2][4]. This contrasts with pyruvate:ferredoxin oxidoreductase (PFOR), which is found in anaerobes and reduces ferredoxin instead[2]. The PDH complex is part of a conserved core of cyanobacterial genes resistant to horizontal gene transfer, indicating its fundamental metabolic role[4].
</gene_function>

<physiological_impact>
The PDH complex directly influences cellular physiology by regulating carbon flux. It provides acetyl-CoA for the TCA cycle, affecting energy production (ATP), reducing equivalents (NADH), and biosynthetic precursors. In cyanobacteria, PDH is indispensable for photoautotrophic growth, as its absence would disrupt the generation of essential metabolites for amino acid, lipid, and cofactor synthesis[2][3]. Mutations in PDH components in other organisms cause severe metabolic disorders, underscoring its physiological criticality[3].
</physiological_impact>
